YANG DI-PERTUAN NEGARA'S SPEECH

(Debate on the Address)
(Third Day)


    Order read for resumption of adjourned debate on Question [4th August, 1960],

    'That the following Address in reply to the speech of the Yang di-Pertuan Negara be agreed to:-

    "We, the Legislative Assembly of the State of Singapore, express our thanks to the Yang di-Pertuan Negara for the speech which he delivered on behalf of the Government at the opening of the present session of this Assembly."'.-(The Prime Minister).

    Question again proposed.

2.32 p.m.

    The Minister for Culture (Mr S. Rajaratnam): Mr Speaker, Sir, I said yesterday that the 16 Hong Lim resolutions were concocted not to save the

Column: 218

country but the flagging political fortunes of the Member for Hong Lim.

    A clue to the whole thing can be found in the Member's speech yesterday. He quoted the Prime Minister's speech in the Assembly in April 1958. The Prime Minister in that speech said that the attention of the people of Singapore was focused on the City Council and that it had captured the hearts and minds of the workers. The day when the Member for Hong Lim was the Mayor of the City Council was the golden age of Singapore politics, for the simple reason that he was the number one bossman. Sir, I do not deny that the P.A.P. City Council captured the hearts and minds of the workers of Singapore. Nor can I deny that the Member for Hong Lim did some good work. But, at the risk of earning his displeasure, I will say - and so do the other P.A.P. Councillors all but one of whom today are P.A.P. Assemblymen on this side of the House - that the former Mayor likes to think that all the credit should go to him. He forgot that it was the Party and not the Mayor or Mr Ong Eng Guan as an individual who won the hearts and minds of the workers. It was this delusion that what the people fell for was his personality which had led him to the present impasse. He wanted people to treat him as a superman, a Tarzan and a Flash Gordon all rolled into one. Therefore, when he was on strained to work as a member of the team in the Cabinet he found the whole thing distasteful. It was inevitable that he should clash with Cabinet colleagues who refused to treat him as a superman. He disliked having to do things which helped to build up the reputation of the Party as a whole. What he enjoyed most was building up a myth of the invincible superman single-handedly fighting against desperate odds. So, Sir, he started first with intrigues within the Cabinet, trying to play one colleague against another. He employed the now familiar technique of 'I, good man. You, good man. But he, bad man.'

Column: 219



    Mr Speaker: Order. I have had occasion in this debate to remind hon. Members of Standing Order 46 (1) which reads:

    "The personal conduct of Members of the Assembly shall not be referred to except upon a substantive motion moved for that purpose."

All these details of the personal conduct of the Member for Hong Lim appear to me to be completely out of order, unless, of course, they are brought forward on a substantive motion. I would also like to remind hon. Members that we are on the Yang di-Pertuan Negara's speech and Standing Order 13 (2) states, inter alia:

    "Debate thereon that is, on the speech shall be confined to the policy of the Government as outlined in the speech and on amendments (if any) moved by Members...".

As I have said before, there may be some bearing on the general state of affairs in Singapore anent the personal conduct of the Member for Hong Lim. But if the Minister embarks on details of the nature he has enunciated, then I think he is out of order.

    Mr Rajaratnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, I myself am not interested in the personal conduct of the Member for Hong Lim, but what I want to point out is the action that he took as a member of the Government within the Government to divert the policies of the Government and subvert the Government. Sir, I shall try to avoid bringing in details and I shall only outline the general technique that was adopted by him.

    Sir, as I said, at first he began by trying to play one Cabinet colleague against the other. When this failed, he then turned on to the Parliamentary Secretaries, trying to win them over with childish inaccuracies, that the Party might cheat them of their pay, that their telephones were being tapped by the secret police, and so on. This got him nowhere. Then he turned to the Assemblymen. That also got him nowhere except for the two who obviously decided to follow him to the other side of the House. But he never tried to convince the Government of the correctness of his stand on the 16 resolutions except to bring them up in this Assembly and which he offers as a panacea for all our troubles.

Column: 220

In fact, his intrigues were never based on the merits or otherwise of the 16 resolutions which have now become a major topic with him. They were based purely on the exploitation of the baser side of human nature, like fear, cupidity and jealousy, all of which were testified to by statements signed by Assemblymen on this side of the House. Of course, he has claimed that these statements were extracted from the Assemblymen by force and intimidation. The Assemblymen concerned are here and it is up to him to challenge any Member on this side of the House to get up and say that he signed these statements by the Party under duress.

    Sir, having failed to make any headway inside the Government among the Cabinet members, Parliamentary Secretaries and Assemblymen, his next target was the party conference of cadres, Assemblymen and branch secretaries held in June. Obviously, a different technique was called for. So he brought in the 16 resolutions in order to get support. Here too, Sir, he lost out and again he explained away his defeat by claiming that those who voted for his expulsion did so because the place, was surrounded by secret police armed with guns. The hundred or so members who were present there knew very well that there were no guns and no secret police. But he was not interested in trying to win over people who obviously had lost any respect they might have had for him. So it has now come to a point where he alleged yesterday that the Cabinet, the Parliamentary Secretaries and the Assemblymen on this side of the House are no longer revolutionary, that they are led by colonial-minded leaders, that they have betrayed the principles of the P.A.P., that this Government is run by the famous trio - Blades, Thomson and Meadows - and that the P.A.P. have achieved nothing during the past year except, of course, the Ministry of National Development. The wonder of it is that if he really believes in what he says now, then how is it that he managed to stay in such a reactionary Government for one year? And he would have stayed on had not the Government decided to precipitate matters by asking him to leave. Or is it

Column: 221

suggested that the P.A.P. has been reactionary only since June - about two months ago - when he was ejected from the Government and from the Party.

    In his speech yesterday, he claimed that he could not see any difference between the policies of the present Government and what he described as the Lim Yew Hock Government. Also to sustain his claim that the P.A.P. is no longer revolutionary, he quoted extensively from the 1954 P.A.P. Manifesto. Sir, it is good to know that the Member for Hong Lim draws spiritual sustenance and inspiration from a document drafted long before he entered the Party by people who are still in the Party. He also quoted extensively and approvingly speeches made by the Prime Minister. It is strange that the Member for Hong Lim should find spiritual nourishment for his anti-colonial spirit from the speeches of a man he now describes as pro-colonialist. Equally noticeable, Sir, is that the Member for Hong Lim at no time quoted any speeches by himself to sustain his anti-colonial flame. I do not think that this was due to any modesty on his part. The sad truth is that there is little relevant material worth quoting from his writings or his speeches. The Member for Hong Lim was one of our leading slogan shouters, slogans generally provided for him by the Party, but he has contributed little to the theory and practice of anti-colonialism. He has been telling us in the last few days how he is going to fight colonialism; but during the last four years - and during the one year he was in the Government - he has never contributed anything by way of any theoretical article to show how best we can fight colonialism. The only major contribution was an article to the P.A.P.'s Fourth Anniversary Souvenir publication, and the only notable thing about this article is its title. It reads "Since I became first Mayor of Singapore". The other contributions to the souvenir dealt with such topics as "Preparing Ourselves", "The New Phase

Column: 222

after Merdeka", "Our Economic Future", "The National Approach to the Problem of Education", and so on. As against such weighty and adult topics, the Member for Hong Lim's contribution was on the subject dearest to his heart - himself. All the four years of struggle of the P.A.P. was not worth noting. What was worth noting by the world at large was "Since I became first Mayor of Singapore". From his point of view, the history of Singapore falls into two periods - before Eng Guan, and after Eng Guan. His resentment against his Party and his colleagues in the Government springs from his belief that they have refused steadfastly to accept him as a man of destiny and a superman. So today he accuses the Government of being reactionary, of being run by pro-colonial leaders, and of being stooges of the famous trio - Blades, Meadows, and Thomson.

    But I think there is one man who thinks otherwise. I intend to call him to testify on our behalf. I know that next to God, this man is held in high esteem by the Member for Hong Lim. That person is no other than the former Minister for National Development. I know for a fact that the Member for Hong Lim will not dismiss the former Minister for National Development as a stooge of the Prime Minister nor as a pro-colonialist, nor as a man who can be intimidated into saying things he does not want to say. I am referring to the speech made by the former Minister for National Development in this House on 21st July, 1959, [Hansard], Vol. 11, No. 6. This was said in the course of a debate on the address of thanks to the Yang di-Pertuan Negara's speech. I am quite sure that as far as the Member for Hong Lim is concerned, there can be no higher authority on any matter. In his speech made yesterday and the day before, the Member for Hong Lim contended that in stressing the limits under which the present Government had to work, we were talking like the Progressive Party and the Lim Yew Hock Government. Yet this is what the former Minister for National Development had to say on 21st July, 1959, Hansard, col. 347, 4th paragraph:

Column: 223



    "Mr Speaker, we understand the limitations of the present Constitution, which do restrain the political power of the elected representatives of the people. We do understand those limitations. We do understand that the elected Government has to work within certain defined powers and that there are curbs and restrictions on those powers and functions which a normal fully elected Government is supposed to exercise."

Was the former Minister for National Development talking like the Lim Yew Hock Government when he said this? Was he saying these things in order to fool the people of Singapore into accepting what the Member for Hong Lim now brands as a pro-colonial constitution? Yesterday, the Member for Hong Lim argued that the present Constitution is unsatisfactory because the British, to quote him, "still exercise control politically and economically and that these controls are more far-reaching in consequence than the control they exercised under the 1953 Constitution." Yet here is what the former Minister for National Development had to say on this subject, at col. 347:

    "Mr Speaker, we also understand that within the island state of Singapore, we also have limitations on our economy, limitations which even a magician turned Minister for Finance cannot solve. I do not envy my colleague, the Minister for Finance, for his heavy tasks. But we the P.A.P., understanding those very limitations, have come up today and accepted the responsibilities of Government because there is no choice left to the people."

This confession places the former Minister for National Development in an awkward spot. From what had been said by the Member for Hong Lim, it could only mean that the former Minister for National Development assumed power and office under a constitution which he knew gave colonialism a tighter grip on the Island's economy. I wish, Sir, that the former Minister for National Development were here to defend himself against the smear that he is a colonial stooge. I am sure he would have dealt with the Member for Hong Lim in a language that would constrain you to call him to order. But fortunately the former Minister for National Development is not here.

Column: 224



    Again, Sir, yesterday the Member for Hong Lim described the Minister for Finance as belonging to the pro-colonial faction of the Government. And yet the former Minister for National Development expressed high regard for the Minister for Finance. In fact, he said that he understood the limitations on our economy which "even a magician turned Minister for Finance cannot solve." And he also said. "I do not envy my colleague, the Minister for Finance." And he went on to say that he could not understand why Members of the Opposition had spent so many days debating and yet were not able to contribute any constructive ideas to the running of the Government machinery but just to attack the Government, especially the Minister for Finance. The Member for Hong Lim also suggested that we were supporters of colonialism if we continued to work under the present Constitution. Yet the former Minister for National Development, after outlining the limitations of the present Constitution, said we would be shirking our duty if we failed to work the present Constitution. I quote col. 347:

    "The masses cannot get what they want - even the basic necessities which any modern Government should be able to provide. And it is the task of the P.A.P. Government, knowing the political and the economic limitations of the present situation, to come up and accept the responsibility of this Government, as we did so in the City Council. When we were in the City Council, our powers were as limited within the framework of the Constitution as our powers now in the present Government are limited within the present framework of the new Constitution. But we will be taking a wrong move if we refuse to accept the responsibility of Government."

Sir, I am not trying to create bad blood between the former Minister for National Development and the Member for Hong Lim, because I know a bond of mutual admiration exists between them. But the point that needs to be clarified is whether the former Minister for National Development was or was not deceiving the people knowingly by saying things which he did not believe to be true.

    The Member for Hong Lim now contends that this Constitution is a fraud and that we should now reopen talks with a view to liquidating the remnants

Column: 225

of colonialism, that is, fight for the independence of Singapore. Yet the former Minister for National Development suggested, in that same speech, the course to be followed in order to gain independence for Singapore. I quote col. 348:

    "Our way is the way of ultimate independence through merger with the Federation, and before that is achieved we have to accept whatever limitations are imposed on this Government by the so-called new Constitution - limitations imposed on us in this island State with no raw materials.

    In the short-term policy - that is, the providing of the basic necessities of life to the 14 million people of this island - and in our long-term policy of attainment of reunification of Singapore and the Federation of Malaya, one thing is paramount and that is, Mr Speaker, the unity of all the communities and the races in Malaya."

That was the strategy that the former Minister for National Development advocated was necessary to achieve independence for Singapore. So, I do not know whether the former Minister would therefore be described as being pro-colonialist or pro-Meadows, Thomson, Blades, or a stooge, if he continued to talk in the fashion that we are talking today.

    Now, it may be that the Member for Hong Lim might - one never knows how he behaves - decide to attack the former Minister for National Development in this fashion, If he has such intentions, may I draw the attention of the Member for Hong Lim to another far-sighted remark made by the former Minister for National Development: the former Minister knew that there would be opportunity for demagogues - and not very bright demagogues at that - to exploit the limitations that the present Constitution imposes. Any petty demagogue, the former Minister for National Development knew, could try to embarrass the Government by taking ultra Left lines. For all I know, he might have had people like the Member for Hong Lim in mind when he made the following observations (col. 348):

    "Because of the limitations of the Constitution, the role of the Opposition is even much more important than ever. The role of the Opposition is to provide constructive criticism to the Government and not just to attack

Column: 226

the Government in all its policies. We have heard speeches from the Opposition Benches and I have not even heard for one single moment any Opposition speaker give any constructive ideas. Perhaps the hon. Members in the Opposition are not capable of doing it. Then what they should do is not to speak too long."

    We have been listening to the 16 resolutions which the Member for Hong Lim and his comrades have been offering the nation for the last two months. Not so long ago, the Member for Hong Lim held a public lecture on "How to Fight Colonialism". None of the speakers put forward any concrete measures on how to fight colonialism. Not one of the speakers was able to put forward as effective a strategy as that put forward by the P.A.P. and endorsed by the former . Minister for National Development. For example, one of the resolutions asked that the Singapore Government should reopen talks with the United Kingdom with a view to revising the Constitution. What we are not told, however, is in what way the Constitution should be revised; If what is asked for is that we should have complete independence, then the former Minister for National Development agreed that it was not practicable for two reasons. First. having regard to the power situation in this part of the world, the British would not agree to such a proposition in any case. Secondly, independence for a small island like Singapore would be a phoney independence. Economically, politically and militarily, even an independent Singapore cannot withstand outside pressures. These are not new arguments. They were thrashed out publicly in the Tanjong Pagar by-election and in public speeches by P.A.P. leaders, in articles and editorials in the Party publications long before the elections. The contention then was that we had no choice but to accept what we described as three-quarters Merdeka, and it was first propounded in the Petir, our Party publication, as far back as May, 1956, three years before the general elections. I have looked through the past issues of Petir for contributions by the Member for Hong Lim for any dissenting opinion from him; and for a man who now poses

Column: 227

as the leading theoretician of anti-colonialism in Singapore, together with the Member for Aljunied, there appear to have been no more than one or two articles in all these four years from him. Nor did he ever raise any objections with any of his Party colleagues during the three years discussion took place about what should be the strategy we should adopt in the particular situation obtaining in Singapore. The choice as we saw it then, and as we see it now, is that we either accepted power under conditions of qualified independence, or left colonialism to carry on through Right-wing forces who would have wiped out not only the Leftwing adventurers but the non-Communist Left as well. That is the choice still, and the Member for Hong Lim, apart from slogans, has not produced one cogent argument or constructive suggestion as to how and why the anti-colonial fight could be carried out by other means. Another of the 16 resolutions demands that we should hold talks with the Federation Government for merger. Fine. But how does he propose that we should do it? Do we summon the Federation leaders and say, "The time has now come to talk of merger, because the Member for Hong Lim says so."? Or do we send an ultimatum to the Federation leaders telling them that either they start talks on merger or else the Member for Hong Lim will invade their territory with his liberation army?

    The Member for Hong Lim knows that we have done everything we can do to get the Federation interested in merger. He also knows that merger will not come simply by demanding it.. He knows that it is a long delicate process of convincing the people of the Federation, in particular the Malays, that they have nothing to fear from merger and everything to gain as a result. The Member for Hong Lim knows all this, because when he was still in the Party he was convinced that our strategy was the best strategy to gain eventual independence for Singapore. The Member for Hong Lim, by bringing forward resolutions which he knows to be impracticable, is doing so in order to offer his services to the Left-wing adventurers who used to twist his tail once

Column: 228

upon a time. In his speech yesterday, he said that he bore no ill-will towards the Left-wing adventurers who tried to oust him from the Party. He did not take this Christian attitude of forgiving his enemies at the time when he was smarting under defeat. He was all for fixing them. But now that he has no longer any following within the P.A.P., he offers his services to these adventurers because, in his present plight, he cannot afford to be choosey.

    As the Prime Minister said the day before what the Left-wing adventurers want is an atmosphere of tension and uncertainty, and that is why the Member for Hong Lim comes forward with resolutions which he knows are impracticable and foolish. But that is the price he has to pay for the support of the adventurers who he thinks would reinstate him into the superman that he thinks he should be. And the Left-wing adventurers have a different reason for wanting the Member for Hong Lim to raise these phoney issues.

    The P.A.P. is a non-Communist socialist Party, and it is necessary for Left-wing adventurers, who are not as clear-headed and as realistic as they should be, to show that a non-Communist socialist Party cannot satisfy the needs of the masses for a better life. They fear probably that the P.A.P. might show the masses that a non-Communist, socialist democracy can work in Singapore, and in Malaya eventually. So it is necessary to take action now to prevent the P.A.P. from succeeding in its experiment, and in order to do that, it is necessary to revive tension and uncertainty to make sure that no economic and stable political development takes place. So that they can say, "There you are. Non-Communist socialism cannot work." Another reason is perhaps that by reviving tension and uncertainty, they hope to drive the P.A.P. into the arms of either the Right-wing, and thus discrediting itself in the eyes of the masses or, they hope, into the arms of the Left-wing adventurers, who have been increasingly disturbed by the fact that the P.A.P., during the last one year, has not accepted any control from them, and has chosen to act independently in

Column: 229

the interest of the P.A.P. and nobody else. And that is a situation which they are not prepared to tolerate. What they want is to create tension to force us into their arms so that they can manipulate the P.A.P. to serve their own interest. Whatever happens, they can be sure that the P.A.P. has no intention of becoming dependent either on the Right or Left-wing adventurers, and the Member for Hong Lim would be better advised to tell his manipulators so.

    Sir, the Member for Hong Lim also complains that the Government was intimidating the Press, and, as a result, his speeches and those of his comrades got only 500 words, and that of Mr George Thomson, he complains, got 2,500 words. It is true that the Government discussed the matter of Ong Eng Guan with the representatives of the local Press. We explained to the Press representatives the nature of the game that the Member for Hong Lim was playing, and that was to whip up tension and agitation by circulating fabricated stories, inaccuracies which he hoped would provide fuel to inflame passions, and, therefore, create a situation in which it could be said that the whole of Singapore has risen in support of the 16 resolutions. He knew that he was not putting forward his point of view or stating his case, but he was quite prepared to use the newspapers to create a situation which could lead to public disorder. There was no intimidation. I explained these things to the Press. In fact, one of the newspapers informed us that they had already decided, after the first Press conference by the Member for Hong Lim - to quote the words of the editor concerned - "to cut out any drivel". They agreed, and we also agreed with them, that if he said anything worthwhile, anything new, anything which was legitimate, they would print it, but that they would keep a look-out for any material which they knew to be either fabricated or calculated to inflame passions, and then they would, of their own accord, cut down stories of that nature.

Column: 230



    For example, the Member for Hong Lim can fabricate news. Let me give a few instances. He made the charge that at the Party conference last June, the place was surrounded by secret police armed with guns. Again he charged that Assemblymen had been intimidated personally by the Prime Minister into denouncing him and his action. In fact, I think the day before yesterday, he even said that an article under my name in the Petir of 14th July was really not written by me but by the Prime Minister. Well, Sir, for something like 15 years I have earned my living by writing for newspapers, and, that being so, I think I am quite capable of writing my own speeches. In fact, that particular article was only a reproduction of a speech I made before 150 Party members, and it was also made impromptu. There was no written script. Secondly, the Prime Minister was not at that meeting, because he happened to be away from Singapore on that day. The Member for Hong Lim knows all that. But he fabricated this story purely in the hope of convincing the people outside that the Minister for Culture is really a pro-Ong Eng Guan man, but that he has been made to say things, he has had his arms twisted by the Prime Minister, who wrote his articles and his speeches. In fact, yesterday, the Member for Hong Lim reached new heights of recklessness by repeating inaccurate statements about Indonesian soldiers invading Singapore. He also tried to exploit the issue of Nanyang University, which he knows is a delicate and highly emotional issue. I would say that the Member for Hong Lim has politically reached the point of no return, and I have no doubt that in the coming month, his remarks will reach new heights of recklessness on the basis of "after me the deluge".

    Again, the Member for Hong Lim raised the issue of the two journalists recently detained. He doubted whether they were really K.M.T. agents. He claimed that they were arrested because they attended his Press conference. Let me briefly give the background of these two journalists.

Column: 231



    Wong Chin Sen, one of the detained journalists, had long worked for K.M.T. papers. In 1956 he was sent for studies in Taiwan and attended a K.M.T. school for cadres on political service, taking what they call a post-graduate course for overseas graduates. This included, Mr Wong admitted, living in a military camp and being taught military drill and discipline. In 1955 he was one of the four K.M.T. personalities behind the organisation of an anti-Communist movement among Rightist students of the Chung Cheng High School. The purpose was to recruit young people to go to Taiwan for higher education, which also included K.M.T. indoctrination and, no doubt, military training as well.

    The other journalist, Loke Peng Lum, had also been long associated with K.M.T. organisations which we regard as subversive organisations, because their purpose is to encourage local citizens to be loyal to the Taiwan Government. Mr Loke also worked for K.M.T. papers and admitted to being a K.M.T. member. He was trained in the Central Military Academy in Hung Chiang.

    So this is the record of the K.M.T. activities that these two journalists had pursued. Prior to their arrest, they were working for the Tiger Press which, since its inception, has consistently published stories which, more often than not, were fabricated and completely false, with the intention of creating dissatisfaction against the present Government.

    This is not surprising for two reasons. First, the proprietor of the concern had instructed the journalists that he wanted anti-P.A.P. stories - stories which would discredit the P.A.P. Secondly, because many of the staff of the Tiger Press consist of journalists who had to get away from Singapore as a result of Government's action against mosquito and yellow publications. So, K.M.T. journalists, graduates of yellow newspapers, a proprietor who has given instructions that all he is interested in are anti-P.A.P. stories - all these three elements conspired together not to publish news but to fabricate stories. We ignored these mischievous stories for a while. In fact, we drew the attention of the

Column: 232

managing editor of the paper that while we did not care two hoots whether they criticised us or not, we would not tolerate fabricated stories prejudicial to the maintenance of public order. In fact, very often, they published stories which were calculated to rouse communal prejudices and hatred. For example, they had a story when there was a controversy over the Nanyang University issue;. claiming that the Prime Minister had decided to boycott the Nanyang University convocation.
